metadata.case_name: Appellant Textile Mill v. State of Bombay

facts.text: The appellant is a cotton textile mill situate in Bombay.
The appellant had been continuously making losses from 1950 to 1955.

References were made under s. 73-A of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act by the Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay, in respect of disputes relating to bonus for the years 1952 and 1953, pending before the Industrial Court, Bombay.
Appellant's case before Industrial Court was that due to losses, no bonus payable for 1952-1953.
Appellant applied for its case to be dealt with separately from other mills' bonus cases, prayer acceded to.
While references pending, agreement arrived between Mill-owners Association, Bombay and Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay, for payment of bonus for 1952 to 1957.
Agreement to come into force for each mill when signed by each member mill of the Mill-owners Association.
Clause 6 of agreement provided for minimum bonus of 4-8% of basic wages even where profit inadequate per Full Bench formula or actual loss, adjustable against future surplus.
Agreement registered and enforceable as award against mills which signed.
Appellant did not sign the agreement, so not enforced against it.
Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh requested Government of Bombay to enforce the award against appellant under s. 114(2).
Government issued notification dated July 31, 1956, directing award of March 13, 1956, for bonus 1952-1953 and 1954-1957 to be enforced against appellant.
Appellant filed writ petition in Bombay High Court challenging constitutionality of s. 114(2) and power of Government to issue notification, dismissed on October 9, 1956.
Appeal to Division Bench of Bombay High Court dismissed.
High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.
Appellant mill member of Mill-owners Association, but did not accept agreement individually.
About 42 out of 47 mills accepted agreement; award made March 13, 1956, in terms of agreement for those mills.
Notification specified award binding on appellant for bonus 1952-1957.

legal_issues.text: Whether s. 114(2) of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1947, is unconstitutional as violating Articles 19(1)(f) and (g) of the Constitution.
Whether the notification dated July 31, 1956, issued under s. 114(2) exceeds the powers conferred on the State Government.
Whether s. 114(2) violates Article 14 of the Constitution by conferring unguided arbitrary power.

petitioner_arguments.text: s. 114(2) unconstitutional as violates fundamental rights under Art. 19(1)(f) and (g).
Notification goes beyond powers under s. 114(2) as it enforces agreement providing minimum bonus despite losses, which Industrial Court could not award.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 114(2) Bombay Industrial Relations Act; precedents like Associated Cement Companies v. Workmen; New Manekchowk Spinning Co. v. Textile Labour Association

petitioner_arguments.text: s. 114(2) offends Art. 14 by giving unguided arbitrary power to discriminate.

respondent_arguments.text: s. 114(2) valid, not arbitrary; power limited to local area, for industrial peace, where Representative Union party.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 114(2), s. 2(23), s. 13(1) Bombay Industrial Relations Act; Art. 14, 19(1)(g)

respondent_arguments.text: Restrictions under s. 114(2) reasonable in interest of general public for industrial peace.
No violation of s. 95A as notification under s. 114(2) not a 'proceeding' binding by Full Bench decisions; agreements can provide bonus despite no profit.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 95A, s. 114(2), s. 115A Bombay Industrial Relations Act

respondent_arguments.text: Notification not mala fide; threat of industrial unrest justified.

court_reasoning.text: Not necessary to decide constitutionality of s. 114(2); notification bad as exceeds State Government's power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power under s. 114(2) co-terminus with Industrial Court's adjudicatory power; cannot direct what adjudicator cannot award.

court_reasoning.text: s. 114(2) power limited by subject-matter and law; bound by Full Bench decisions under s. 95A and Supreme Court precedents.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot enforce agreement imposing minimum bonus in loss-making years, as Industrial Court lacks jurisdiction per precedents.

court_reasoning.text: Agreement similar to one in New Manekchowk case; cannot be imposed against will of party via adjudication or s. 114(2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: State Government cannot do what Industrial Court cannot.

court_reasoning.text: Dissent (Sarkar J.): s. 114(2) constitutional; not arbitrary, reasonable for industrial peace; not bound by s. 95A as notification not 'proceeding'; agreements valid even for bonus without profit.

holdings.text: Notification dated July 31, 1956, beyond powers under s. 114(2) and quashed.
Power under s. 114(2) co-extensive with adjudicatory power under the Act; cannot enforce minimum bonus where no profit/loss.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mill-owners Association, Bombay v. Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh
precedents_cited.relevance: Full Bench formula for prior charges before bonus.

precedents_cited.case_name: New Manekchowk Spinning Co. Ltd. v. Textile Labour Association
precedents_cited.relevance: Agreement imposing bonus despite losses cannot be enforced by adjudication against unwilling party.

precedents_cited.case_name: Associated Cement Companies Ltd. v. Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: No bonus payable where no available surplus after prior charges.

precedents_cited.case_name: Muir Mills Co. Ltd. v. Suti Mills Mazdoor Union
precedents_cited.relevance: No bonus where no profit made.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bijay Cotton Mills v. State of Ajmer
precedents_cited.relevance: Individual hardship does not invalidate reasonable restrictions.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to extend agreement/award to non-parties limited to what adjudicator can award; bound by Full Bench law.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenges to constitutionality of s. 114(2); not decided by majority.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; notification dated July 31, 1956 quashed as beyond powers under s. 114(2); no prejudice to pending/future bonus references to be decided per Associated Cement precedent.
outcome.relief_granted: Quashing of notification; appeal allowed with costs.

key_quotes.text: The State Government's power to make a direction under that section is co-terminus with the power of an adjudicator be it a labour court, an Industrial Court or a wage board under the Act to make an award thereunder.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We do not think that s. 114(2) authorises the State Government to act against the law as laid down by the legislature or by this Court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits government power to legal bounds.

key_quotes.text: The power given by the provision is not, in my view, uncontrolled.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Sarkar J. on no Art. 14 violation.
